Award.AwardTitle: Electrochemical Nano-manufacturing of Multi-segment Magnetic Structures to Introduce "Color Contrast" to Magnetic Resonance Imaging

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funding to develop magnetic nanostructures as contrast agents (CAs) with controllable shape, size, chemistry and more importantly local magnetic field to introduce frequency dependent nuclear magnetic resonance(NMR) signals. These signals will be reconstructed to form "color" magnetic resonance images (MRIs). Compared to the current MRI which can only provide grey scale images, the new technology can have significantly improved resolution, sensitivity and capability of indentify different types of CAs. Proposed research focuses on developing non-traditional nanomanufacturing approaches to fabricate multicomponent nanostructures with desirable properties for bio-medical applications. Compared to traditional lithographic and physical synthesis methods, the new approach will effectively lower cost, increase yield and improve quality control through the combination of a unique nanoporous template synthesis method and controlled electrochemical deposition technique for nano-manufacturing.

If successful, this research will develop nano-manufacturing techniques capable of producing non-spherical, muti-component and biocompatible nanomaterials with precise size, shape and composition control at levels that are difficult to achieve by other synthesis methods. Through careful design, multi-component nanomaterials can deliver a wide range of functionalities that are difficult to realize in conventional spherical particles. This ability to create diverse shapes and functionalites will then be used to create next generation MRI with three-segment CAs with discreet localized magnetic fields. The net effect is that these contrast agents will offer differing response with changing frequency. Similar to the impacts of introduction of color decoration in optical imaging using dyes and fluorophores, the introduction of "color" contrasts in MRI will significantly improve disease diagnosis efficiency, accuracy and sensitivity. In addition, these anisotropic nanostructures will have other multi-functionalities that can be utilized in targeted delivery, tissue engineering and localized treatment. In addition, the boarder impact of the project on society will also be reflected through the integrated research and educational program development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanomterials and nanostructures can bring new properties and functionalities that are not presented in conventional natural materials. This is especially true and useful for biomedical and energy applications. Nanotechnology has been in the past largely driven by the semiconductor industry, where minimizing device size, increasing speed and lowering energy consumption are critical. However the lithographic based material fabrication and processing techniques are limited by cost, throughput and complication thus often not suitable for nanoscale bio-materials fabrication. In project is inspired by the need of nanomaterials with nontraditional shape (non-spherical or cylindrical) and multi-composition for bio-medical application. One of such application is the dumbbell or tube shaped mangetic nanoparticles used as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). With controllable localized magnetic fields, these nanostructure can introduce frequency response and thus generate color MRI pictures. To mass produce such non-uniform nanostructure, we developed a multilayer nanoporous membrane using nuclear track etching technology, so that the pore size in different layer of the membrane can be controlled. Using these membranes, we electrochemically deposit functional materials into the pores or further use the deposited materials as templates to fabricate various nanostructures with controlled size, shape and composition. These membrane can be used a template platform for the nano-manufacturing of a wide range of nanostructures that are difficult if not impossible to produce by traditional fabrication techniques.

This multilayer membrane fabrication and electrochemical nano-manufacturing synthesis has been further developed into a roll-to-roll production process, so that the nanostructures with unconventional shape and functionality can cost effectively mass produced. We have demonstrate the fabrication of segment nanowire arrays as glucose sensor for blood sugar measurement.

Both the multilayered nanoporous membrane and segmented nanowire array sensors have been filed with US patent office, This four year project not only supported the research and development of functional materials nano-manufacturing, it also has broader impact on society through graduate student training, undergraduate research support, and STEM outreach to local high schools and general public. Since 2013, PI established an “Intro to Cougar Engineering” program which brings STEM education to local minority high school juniors and seniors. Starting with 30 students, this 2-day program now attracts more than 200 students to University of Houston to learn about science and engineering and participate in an engineering competition.


Last Modified: 10/13/2015
Modified by: Li Sun
